expanded_description: The elimination method (also called the addition method) solves systems of equations by combining the equations to eliminate one variable. This method is particularly powerful when coefficients are opposites or when we can easily create opposites. Unlike substitution, elimination often avoids fractions and can be more efficient for certain types of systems.

core_concept.principle: To solve a system by elimination: (1) Write both equations in standard form $Ax + By = C$. (2) If necessary, multiply one or both equations by constants so that the coefficients of one variable are opposites. (3) Add the equations to eliminate that variable. (4) Solve the resulting equation for the remaining variable. (5) Substitute back to find the other variable. (6) Check the solution.
core_concept.explanation: Think of elimination as combining two scales to cancel out one weight. If one scale has +3x and another has -3x, adding them makes the x's disappear, leaving only y terms. This lets you solve for y directly, then find x. It's like solving a puzzle where matching pieces cancel each other out.

sections.introduction: Elimination is especially efficient when coefficients are already opposites or can be easily made opposites.

key_concept.definition:
Elimination is particularly useful when:
• Coefficients of a variable are already opposites (e.g., $2x$ and $-2x$)
• Coefficients are the same (subtraction works instead of addition)
• One equation can be multiplied by a small integer to create opposites
• Avoiding fractions is desirable
key_concept.context: Recognizing when elimination is efficient saves time and reduces algebraic errors.

sections.introduction: When coefficients are opposites, adding the equations eliminates that variable immediately.

key_concept.definition: If the coefficients of a variable are opposites (e.g., $3y$ and $-3y$), add the two equations to eliminate that variable. The result is a single equation in one variable.
key_concept.context: This is the simplest form of elimination—no multiplication needed, just addition.

worked_examples.title: Elimination by Adding
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each system by adding the equations:
a) $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 7 \\ 2x - 3y = 1 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} 4x + 5y = 12 \\ -4x + 3y = 4 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} 3x - 2y = 8 \\ -3x + 5y = -2 \end{cases}$
worked_examples.concept_applied: When coefficients are opposites, add to eliminate that variable.

process_flow.description: Look for a variable with coefficients that are opposites (e.g., $3y$ and $-3y$).
process_flow.mechanism: If found, adding will eliminate that variable.

process_flow.description: Add the left sides together and the right sides together.
Substitute the found value into one of the original equations.

sections.introduction: When coefficients are the same (not opposites), subtracting the equations eliminates that variable.

key_concept.definition: If the coefficients of a variable are the same (e.g., $3x$ and $3x$), subtract one equation from the other to eliminate that variable. Be careful with signs when subtracting.
key_concept.context: Subtraction is just adding the negative of the second equation. It's often easier to multiply the second equation by -1 and then add.

image.alt: Example: 3x + 2y = 8 and 3x - y = 5 subtract to get 3y = 3
image.caption: Figure 7.5.16: Subtracting eliminates x.

worked_examples.title: Elimination by Subtracting
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each system by subtracting the equations:
a) $\begin{cases} 3x + 2y = 8 \\ 3x - y = 5 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} 5x - 2y = 12 \\ 5x + 3y = 7 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} 4x + 3y = 10 \\ 4x - 2y = 6 \end{cases}$
worked_examples.concept_applied: When coefficients are the same, subtract to eliminate that variable.

sections.introduction: Sometimes we need to multiply one equation by a constant to create opposite coefficients.

introduction_image.alt: Multiplying one equation to create opposites
introduction_image.caption: Figure 7.5.19: Multiplying one equation.

key_concept.definition: If coefficients are not opposites or the same, multiply one equation by a constant to make them so. Choose a multiplier that will make the coefficients of one variable opposites. Then add the equations.
key_concept.context: This extends elimination to systems where simple addition/subtraction isn't directly possible.

image.alt: Example: 2x + 3y = 7 and 4x - y = 5, multiply second by 3
image.caption: Figure 7.5.20: Creating opposites by multiplication.

sections.introduction: Sometimes both equations need to be multiplied to create opposite coefficients.

key_concept.definition: When no simple multiplier works for one equation, multiply both equations by different constants to create opposite coefficients. Choose multipliers that make the coefficients of one variable opposites (LCM of the absolute values).
key_concept.context: This is the most general form of elimination and works for any system.

sections.introduction: Elimination can also reveal when a system has no solution or infinitely many solutions.

key_concept.definition:
When using elimination:
• If all variables cancel and the result is a true statement (like $0 = 0$), the system has infinitely many solutions (dependent).
• If all variables cancel and the result is a false statement (like $0 = 5$), the system has no solution (inconsistent).
key_concept.context: This is the algebraic equivalent of coincident lines (infinite solutions) or parallel lines (no solution).

worked_examples.concept_applied: When variables cancel, check the resulting statement: true = infinite solutions, false = no solution.

sections.section_title: 7.5.7 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Students often make specific mistakes when using elimination. Awareness helps prevent these errors.

classifications.value: Mistakes with signs when adding or subtracting equations.
characteristics: Adding when should subtract, or vice versa

examples.process: Error: Subtracting $3x - 2y = 5$ from $3x + 2y = 9$ as $(3x+2y) - (3x-2y) = 9-5$ giving $4y = 4$ is correct. Better error: Forgetting to distribute negative when subtracting.
examples.explanation: When subtracting, subtract ALL terms, not just the first.

classifications.value: Multiplying only part of an equation.
characteristics: Multiplying only the variable terms, forgetting constants
Not multiplying both sides of the equation

classifications.value: Not verifying the solution in both original equations.

examples.explanation: Correct: Always substitute back to verify

worked_examples.title: Correcting Elimination Errors
worked_examples.problem: A student solved $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 7 \\ 4x - y = 5 \end{cases}$ by multiplying the first by -2 and got $x = 2$, $y = 1$. Is this correct?

step_by_step.explanation: Student got $y = 1$, which would require $-7(1) = -9$? No.
step_by_step.calculation: Student likely added incorrectly: $-4x - 6y + 4x - y = -7y$, right side $-14 + 5 = -9$, so $y = 9/7$

worked_examples.final_answer: Correct solution is $(\frac{11}{7}, \frac{9}{7})$. Student made an arithmetic error.

image.caption: Figure 7.5.35: Common errors summary.

sections.introduction: Apply your skills to solve a variety of systems by elimination.

worked_examples.problem:

3) $\begin{cases} 5x + 2y = 12 \\ 3x - 4y = 2 \end{cases}$ (multiply both)
4) $\begin{cases} 4x + 3y = 10 \\ 8x + 6y = 20 \end{cases}$ (special case)

summary: The elimination method solves systems of equations by combining the equations to eliminate one variable. When coefficients are opposites, add the equations. When coefficients are the same, subtract them (or add the negative). When coefficients aren't suited for direct elimination, multiply one or both equations by constants to create opposite coefficients. Always write equations in standard form $Ax + By = C$ before beginning. After eliminating one variable, solve for the remaining variable, then back-substitute to find the other. Check solutions in both original equations. During elimination, if all variables cancel, examine the result: a true statement (like $0 = 0$) means infinitely many solutions; a false statement (like $0 = 5$) means no solution. Elimination is often more efficient than substitution when coefficients are already aligned and can avoid fractions. Mastering elimination provides a powerful algebraic tool for solving systems and is essential for more advanced mathematics.
